verses.text: The proverbs of Solomon: A wise son brings joy to his father, but a foolish son is a sorrow to his mother.
verses.comment: Solomon’s proverbs distinguish between wisdom and folly as reflected in parent-child relationships. The family structure here is foundational to biblical teachings on authority and virtue.

verses.text: Treasures gained by wickedness do not profit, but righteousness delivers from death.
verses.comment: Righteousness is repeatedly linked to salvation. Spiritual interpretation here suggests a foreshadowing of the ultimate deliverance through Christ (Rom. 6:23).

verses.text: The LORD does not let the righteous go hungry, but He thwarts the craving of the wicked.
verses.comment: God’s providence is emphasized. Also spiritually points to the Bread of Life (John 6:35) who ultimately satisfies the righteous.

verses.text: Lazy hands make poverty, but diligent hands bring wealth.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the virtue of industriousness, foundational to stewardship teachings.

verses.text: He who gathers crops in summer is wise, but he who sleeps during harvest is disgraceful.
verses.comment: Refers to readiness and responsibility in spiritual matters as well as practical life. Parallels to being watchful and prepared in faith (Matt. 25:1–13).

verses.text: Blessings crown the head of the righteous, but violence covers the mouth of the wicked.
verses.comment: ‘Blessings’ are both temporal and spiritual, hinting at a divine favor upon those who live uprightly.

verses.text: The memory of the righteous is a blessing, but the name of the wicked will rot.
verses.comment: Remembrance is tied closely to sanctity and legacy. Spiritual meaning connects to the veneration and commemoration of the holy.

verses.text: The wise in heart accept commands, but a babbling fool will be ruined.
verses.comment: True wisdom is shown by obedience; folly is shown by empty speech. Obedience here is central to both spiritual growth and proper understanding of divine guidance.

verses.text: Whoever walks in integrity walks securely, but he who takes crooked paths will be found out.
verses.comment: Integrity provides true security; one’s actions eventually come to light (see also Luke 8:17).

verses.text: A winking eye causes trouble, and a babbling fool will be ruined.
verses.comment: Subtle deceit is denounced, aligning with New Testament teachings against hypocrisy.

verses.text: The mouth of the righteous is a fountain of life, but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.
verses.comment: Language gives life or destruction. Seen in Christ’s reproach of evil speech (Matt. 12:34–37).

verses.text: Hatred stirs up conflict, but love covers all sins.
verses.comment: The principle that love covers sins echoes grace and mercy (see James 5:20), prefiguring the New Testament doctrine of forgiveness.

verses.text: Wisdom is found on the lips of the discerning, but a rod is for the back of him who lacks sense.
verses.comment: Divine discipline is part of wisdom. Does not shy from the reality of correction as a spiritual good.

verses.text: Wise people store up knowledge, but the mouth of the fool invites ruin.
verses.comment: “Storing knowledge” parallels the importance of tradition and faithful preservation of doctrine.

verses.text: The wealth of the rich is their fortified city, but poverty is the ruin of the poor.
verses.comment: Both literal and spiritual: Temporal riches can provide safety but are secondary to spiritual wealth.

verses.text: The labor of the righteous leads to life, but the earnings of the wicked bring sin.
verses.comment: Righteous labor is part of the journey to sanctification. Points to the Christian call to good works (Eph. 2:10).

verses.text: Whoever heeds discipline is on the way to life, but ignoring correction leads others astray.
verses.comment: Acceptance of correction is necessary for spiritual progress. Note the communal impact of individual choices, a pattern found in the early Church.

verses.text: Whoever conceals hatred has lying lips, and whoever spreads slander is a fool.
verses.comment: Denunciation of slander, consistent with the biblical call to truth and charity.

verses.text: Where words are many, sin is not absent, but whoever restrains his lips is wise.
verses.comment: Restraint in speech is a recurring theme, see James’s admonition regarding the tongue.

verses.text: The tongue of the righteous is choice silver, but the heart of the wicked is worth little.
verses.comment: The value of sustained righteous speech, importance in life and worship.

verses.text: The lips of the righteous feed many, but fools die for lack of sense.
verses.comment: Righteous teaching nourishes spiritually; echoes the New Testament emphasis on sound teaching and apostolic succession.

verses.text: The blessing of the LORD brings wealth, and He adds no sorrow to it.
verses.comment: Divine blessing is the source of true prosperity, contrasting earthly striving.

verses.text: To do wrong is like fun to a fool, but wisdom is pleasure to a person of understanding.
verses.comment: True joy comes from wisdom and godliness.

verses.text: What the wicked dreads will happen to him, but the desire of the righteous will be granted.
verses.comment: God’s justice ensures fulfillment of the righteous and the fall of the wicked.

verses.text: When the storm has passed, the wicked are gone, but the righteous stand firm forever.
verses.comment: Endurance of the righteous is a principle that spiritualizes in the endurance of the faithful community.

verses.text: Like vinegar to the teeth and smoke to the eyes, so is the sluggard to those who send him.
verses.comment: Negligence causes irritation and disappointment, teaches responsibility in one’s vocation.

verses.text: The fear of the LORD adds length to life, but the years of the wicked are cut short.
verses.comment: “Fear of the LORD” links reverence with spiritual and temporal blessing.

verses.text: The hope of the righteous brings joy, but the expectation of the wicked will perish.
verses.comment: Sustained hope is a fruit of faith. Connects to New Testament virtue of hope.

verses.text: The way of the LORD is a refuge for the upright, but destruction comes to evildoers.
verses.comment: ‘Way’ here signifies guidance in both moral and spiritual life.

verses.text: The righteous will never be uprooted, but the wicked will not remain in the land.
verses.comment: Security of the righteous prefigures eternal inheritance—see Matt. 5:5.

verses.text: The mouth of the righteous brings forth wisdom, but a perverse tongue will be cut off.
verses.comment: Speaks to the promise that truth will endure. Also hints at spiritual discipline and doctrinal purity.

verses.text: The lips of the righteous know what is pleasing, but the mouth of the wicked only what is perverse.
verses.comment: Moral discernment is rooted in virtue. There is an implication here for the shaping of conscience.
